data.title: A look at Michigan State's embattled board of trustees
data.meta_description: MSU's eight-member board has come under fire for the university's response to the Larry Nassar sex-abuse scandal
data.text:
Former Michigan Gov. John Engler speaks at a press conference at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building after he was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

The Michigan State University Board of Trustees has been under heavy fire as the fallout continues over the Larry Nassar sex-abuse scandal. Calls for the eight, publicly-elected board members to step down have come from near and far, including students and faculty, state lawmakers, and a slew of newspaper editorial boards.

As more scrutiny has been leveled on the board for what many view as the university’s failure to effectively respond to the Nassar scandal, some readers have asked the question: Just who exactly are the eight members of the board, and what are their qualifications?

Here’s a look at each of the members, who are elected to eight-year terms by a statewide vote.

Related: Despite calls for resignation, Michigan State's trustees say they're not going anywhere

Trustee Brian Breslin speaks during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

Brian Breslin

Breslin, a Republican who serves as chair of the board, was elected in 2011. His term ends at the end of this year, and he announced last month – amid mounting scrutiny over the Nassar scandal – that he would not seek another term.

Recently, he took a leave of absence from his job in Gov. Rick Snyder’s administration, where he served as manager of the governor’s appointments division. In a statement, Breslin said he was doing so to concentrate more on his work as a trustee.

At Friday's board meeting, he addressed the concerns students and faculty have voiced about the board, saying he that he believes "what trust you don't have in us, what confidence you don't have in us, can be restored to this board and future boards."

Breslin, who earned a bachelor’s degree in food systems economics and management from MSU in 1977, retired from retail giant Meijer in 2006, according to his bio. He started with the company after graduating from MSU and worked his way up the company to the position of senior vice president of human resources and government relations.

During his time at Meijer, Breslin also worked as vice president for public and consumer affairs, as well as the company’s spokesperson.

Trustee Joel I. Ferguson (furthest to the right) watches during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

Joel Ferguson

Ferguson, a Democrat who graduated from MSU in 1965, was elected to the board in 1986 and has been reelected three times.

Most recently, he drew criticism for remarks he made during a radio interview prior to former President Lou Anna Simon's decision to step down amid growing outcry over MSU's response to the Nassar scandal.

In that interview, Ferguson defended Simon, saying she would not step down and that she was the best president the university has "ever had." He also said there was more happening at MSU than "just this Nassar thing." Ferguson later apologized for his remarks.

Ferguson is a businessman from the Lansing area, and is “the owner and operator of many major office buildings” in the region, according to his bio. He’s also vice chairmen of the Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan Foundation, and the founder and co-founder of two Lansing television stations.

A U.S. Marine Corps veteran, Ferguson was appointed by Gov. Rick Snyder in February 2016 to the Flint Receivership Transition Advisory Board. He was also appointed to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage board of directors by President Bill Clinton.

Trustee Dianne Byrum speaks during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

Dianne Byrum

Byrum, a partner at Byrum & Fisk Advocacy Communications, is in her second-term on the board, having been first elected in 2008 and reelected in 2016.

She was the second board member – following trustee Mitch Lyons – to call on former MSU President Lou Anna Simon to resign amid growing outrage over the university's response to the Nassar scandal.

At the time, she said: "It is clear that the public has lost confidence in the current administration of Michigan State University, and changes are needed to move the university forward,"

Byrum, a Democrat, has a long history in state politics. She was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives in 1991 and the state Senate in 1995, according to her bio. In 2002, she returned to the House, where she served as Michigan House Democratic Leader.

From 1983 to 1990, she was a member of the Ingham County Board of Commissioners.

Michigan State Trustee Melanie Foster walks into a special Michigan State University Board of Trustees meeting on Friday, Jan. 26, 2018 at the administration building on campus in East Lansing, where Bill Beekman was announced the acting president after former President Lou Anna Simon resigned amid the fallout from the school's Larry Nassar scandal. Jake May | MLive.com

Melanie Foster

Foster, a Republican from East Lansing, was elected to the board in 2004 and reelected in 2014.

The board has faced criticism from some students and faculty who say the decision to appoint former Gov. John Engler as interim president was rushed and that they didn’t have input about the decision.

During a recent board meeting, Foster said she and her fellow trustees met with faculty- and student-liaisons to the board, and that she left that meeting “feeling optimistic about how we can continue on a collaborative effort.”

According to her bio, Foster was first appointed to MSU’s board in 1991 by Engler and left the office in 1992.

An MSU alum, Foster spent 15 years as the president and CEO of commercial landscape company, according to her bio. She also spent 10 years as president and CEO of a commercial landscape firm in Orlando, Fla., that specialized in theme park projects.

She serves as chair of the MSU board’s finance committee, as well as the investment advisory subcommittee.

Trustee Dan Kelly looks on during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler speaks was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

Dan Kelly

Kelly, a Republican from Clarkston who works as an attorney, is serving his first time on the board after being elected in November 2016. He previously sat on the Oakland Community College Board of Trustees for six years.

During Friday’s board meeting, he addressed the decision to appoint Engler as interim president, saying the board acted swiftly because the university was in “crisis mode,” and that “it was in the best interest of the university to “get somebody with boots on the ground … that could handle the crisis that was here.”

According to his bio, Kelly is a member of the board of directors for Giarmarco, Mullins, and Horton, PC, a law-firm based in Troy. He earned his bachelor’s degree from Western Michigan University and his law degree from the Detroit Mercy School of Law.

Trustee Mitch Lyons, middle,watches during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

Mitch Lyons

Lyons, a Republican from Rockford in Kent County, was elected to the board in 2010.

A former football player at MSU, Lyons was the first board member to call for Simon's resignation. Doing so, Lyons said, was the first step to "allow the healing process to begin, first and foremost for the survivors and secondarily for our university."

Lyons, amid the fallout over the Nassar scandal, announced he would not seek another term on the board once his current term expires at the end of the year.

Lyons, who after graduating went on to play in the NFL for several years, owns Lyons Kitzrow Wealth Management, a business that provides investment management and retirement planning services, according to his bio.

He landed in the news in January when he arraigned on misdemeanor assault and batter charges in Jackson County District Court. At the time, Lyons' attorney, Brian Lennon, issued a statement that the "overall situation is a misunderstanding."

Trustee Brian Mosallam, middle, speaks during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

Brian Mosallam

Mosallam, a Democrat from Dearborn, was elected to the board in 2012. He’s been, perhaps, the most publicly visible member of the board in the wake of the Nassar scandal.

He hosted a town hall meeting on Feb. 1 at the Kellogg Hotel and Conference Center, an event that drew more than 600 students, faculty and staff to discuss the issue of sexual assault on campus and the board's decision to hire Engler as interim president.

While the board unanimously voted to hire Engler, Mosallam said he understood the concerns raised by students and faculty, and that he agreed to vote in favor of hiring Engler “for the sake of unification.” Mosallam also said he’s met with student government groups that represent undergraduate and graduate students.

Mosallam graduated from MSU with an engineering arts degree and played football at the university from 1992 to 1996, according to his bio. He works as a financial adviser at AXA Advisors, a French multi-national insurance firm with offices in Michigan.

Trustee George Perles watches during an MSU Board of Trustees meeting at the Michigan State University Hannah Administration Building on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2018. Former Michigan Gov. John Engler was named the interim president of MSU by the Board of Trustees. (J. Scott Park | Mlive.com)

George Perles

Perles, a Democrat who served as MSU’s football coach from 1983 to 1994, was elected to the board in 2007 and reelected in 2014. An army veteran, Perles earned his bachelor’s degree from the university in 1960 and went on to receive his master’s degree in educational administration from MSU in 1961.
